hedline.hl1: Of the Courts And Home Contractors

block.p: ''One Home's Unplanned Addition: A Courtroom'' (Oct. 1) offered a cautionary tale about how disputes between homeowners and contractors can escalate. ''One Home's Unplanned Addition: A Courtroom'' (Oct. 1) offered a cautionary tale about how disputes between homeowners and contractors can escalate. But I would suggest that in the case described in the article, the decision to use a lawyered adversarial process was the essential mistake.

An alternative would have been to settle the dispute with the help of a neutral individual, skilled in conflict resolution techniques and having an in-depth knowledge of construction. Such mediation is confidential and nonbinding, and the settlements are crafted by the parties themselves, allowing creative and cost-effective solutions to be considered.
JOSEPH GRYNBAUM West Hartford, Conn., Oct. 1
The writer is principal of Mediation Resolution International.
